Introduction

Adenomyosis is a benign gynecological condition characterized by an abnormal collection of endometrial glands and stroma within the myometrium, the muscular wall of the uterus.  Patients often present with dysmenorrhea and abnormal uterine bleeding.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Although the exact pathogenesis is unclear, adenomyosis may occur due to endometrial invagination into the myometrium during periods of myometrial weakening or changes in vascularity at the endomyometrial interface.  Therefore, risk factors are often related to these pathologic changes, which include:



  • Age:  more common in women age 40-50
  • Multiparity:  particularly in patients with uterine trauma during delivery (eg, postpartum hemorrhage requiring uterine curettage)
  • Prior uterine surgery:  cesarean delivery, myomectomy

Pathology



Adenomyosis has a gross appearance of areas of dark red endometrial tissue within the myometrium.  The lesions may be diffuse or focal, and the affected areas often display myometrial hypertrophy and hyperplasia, resulting in a globular, enlarged uterus.  Histopathology, which provides the definitive diagnosis, reveals the endometrial glands and stroma within the uterine myometrium (

image 1
).

Clinical presentation



Patients with adenomyosis (

figure 1
) may experience a range of symptoms, including:



  • Heavy menstrual bleeding characterized by heavy, cyclic menses caused by an enlarged uterus and increased endometrial cavity surface area
  • Painful menses (dysmenorrhea) due to cyclic accumulation of endometrial tissue within the myometrium
  • Tender, boggy, symmetrically enlarged ("globular") uterus due to continued endometrial gland accumulation.  The uterus does not typically exceed a size equivalent to that at 12 weeks gestation.  Some patients develop chronic pelvic pain.


Patients with adenomyosis often have concurrent gynecologic conditions, including endometriosis and uterine leiomyomata.  Imaging studies can help delineate these etiologies, but many of the management strategies for these conditions are similar.

Diagnosis



A presumptive diagnosis of adenomyosis can be made based on a combination of clinical evaluation and imaging studies (eg, transvaginal ultrasonography [first-line], MRI).  Imaging of patients with adenomyosis typically shows an enlarged uterus, asymmetric myometrial thickening, and hypoechoic areas in the myometrium (consistent with endometrial stroma and glands).



No laboratory studies are used to diagnose adenomyosis, but some are performed to rule out other conditions and to evaluate for complications.  These include a complete blood count (to evaluate for anemia), pregnancy test, and possible endometrial biopsy in patients at high risk for endometrial hyperplasia/cancer (eg, obesity, anovulation).

Differential diagnosis



  • Primary dysmenorrhea:  causes painful menses, but patients typically have decreased pain by the first 2 days of the menstrual period, rather than throughout the entire menstrual period (like adenomyosis).
  • Endometriosis:  can cause painful menses throughout the entire menstrual period, but because endometriosis is endometrial tissue outside of the uterus, it does not cause a diffusely enlarged, boggy uterus.
  • Uterine fibroids (leiomyoma) (
    figure 2
    ):  also cause heavy, regular menses.  Fibroids can be distinguished from adenomyosis on either pelvic examination, which can show an irregularly enlarged uterus, or pelvic ultrasound, which shows the fibroids.

Management and prognosis



The management of adenomyosis depends on the severity of symptoms and the patient's desire for future fertility.



First-line management is nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs for pain relief.  Hormonal contraception, such as combined estrogen/progestin oral contraceptive pills, progestin-releasing intrauterine devices, and GnRH agonists, are also used for pain management and menstrual regulation.  Most patients experience improvement or resolution of symptoms after menopause, at which time medical management can be discontinued.



For patients who do not respond to medical management or who do not desire future fertility, surgical management with hysterectomy is the definitive treatment and provides a histologic diagnosis.

Summary
